<|ref|>title<|/ref|><|det|>[[97, 118, 379, 144]]<|/det|>
# Cambridge IGCSE™  

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[97, 170, 183, 187]]<|/det|>
## PHYSICS  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[97, 194, 332, 210]]<|/det|>
Paper 1 Multiple Choice (Core)  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[782, 170, 905, 186]]<|/det|>
0625/12  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[782, 194, 905, 210]]<|/det|>
May/June 2024  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[814, 217, 905, 232]]<|/det|>
45 minutes  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[97, 247, 507, 264]]<|/det|>
You must answer on the multiple choice answer sheet.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[97, 277, 437, 293]]<|/det|>
You will need: Multiple choice answer sheet  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[215, 291, 539, 320]]<|/det|>
Soft clean eraser Soft pencil (type B or HB is recommended)  

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[97, 337, 228, 352]]<|/det|>
## INSTRUCTIONS  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[97, 354, 880, 522]]<|/det|>
INSTRUCTIONS- There are forty questions on this paper. Answer all questions.- For each question there are four possible answers A, B, C and D. Choose the one you consider correct and record your choice in soft pencil on the multiple choice answer sheet.- Follow the instructions on the multiple choice answer sheet.- Write in soft pencil.- Write your name, centre number and candidate number on the multiple choice answer sheet in the spaces provided unless this has been done for you.- Do not use correction fluid.- Do not write on any bar codes.- You may use a calculator.- Take the weight of \(1.0 \text{kg}\) to be \(9.8 \text{N}\) (acceleration of free fall \(= 9.8 \text{m/s}^2\)).  

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[97, 549, 220, 564]]<|/det|>
## INFORMATION  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[97, 565, 570, 613]]<|/det|>
INFORMATION- The total mark for this paper is 40.- Each correct answer will score one mark.- Any rough working should be done on this question paper.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[269, 847, 728, 864]]<|/det|>
This document has 16 pages. Any blank pages are indicated.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 72, 97, 89]]<|/det|>
<label>4</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 72, 591, 89]]<|/det|>
Which statement about the weight of an object is correct?

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 100, 133, 117]]<|/det|>
<label>A</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 100, 670, 117]]<|/det|>
The weight of an object is the gravitational force per unit mass.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 127, 133, 144]]<|/det|>
<label>B</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[151, 127, 660, 144]]<|/det|>
The weight of an object is the gravitational force on an object.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 153, 131, 170]]<|/det|>
<label>C</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[151, 153, 887, 170]]<|/det|>
The weight is zero when the object is falling at constant speed in the Earth's atmosphere.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 179, 133, 196]]<|/det|>
<label>D</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[151, 179, 670, 196]]<|/det|>
The weight is zero when the object is in orbit around the Earth.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 500, 106, 518]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 500, 920, 549]]<|/det|> A pulse of sound is produced at the bottom of a boat. The sound travels through the water and is reflected from a shoal of fish. The sound reaches the boat again 1.2 s after it is produced. The speed of sound in the water is \(1500 \text{m/s}\). <|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[361, 555, 635, 667]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 680, 586, 698]]<|/det|> How far below the bottom of the boat is the shoal of fish? <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 708, 133, 726]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 708, 203, 726]]<|/det|> 450 m <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[280, 708, 298, 726]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[310, 708, 373, 726]]<|/det|> 900 m <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[460, 708, 480, 726]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[490, 708, 551, 726]]<|/det|> 1800 m <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[615, 708, 635, 726]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[648, 708, 715, 726]]<|/det|> 3600 m <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 755, 106, 772]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 755, 700, 772]]<|/det|> The frequency of a sound wave increases from \(31 000 \text{Hz}\) to \(32 000 \text{Hz}\). <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 785, 836, 802]]<|/det|> What is the nature of the wave and how does it sound to a human with normal hearing? <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 813, 133, 831]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 813, 544, 831]]<|/det|> It is a longitudinal wave with a decreasing pitch. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 840, 133, 857]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 840, 544, 857]]<|/det|> It is a transverse wave with an increasing pitch. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 866, 133, 884]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 866, 796, 884]]<|/det|> It is a longitudinal wave that cannot be heard by a human with normal hearing. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 892, 133, 910]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 892, 789, 910]]<|/det|> It is a transverse wave that cannot be heard by a human with normal hearing.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 72, 107, 89]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 72, 717, 89]]<|/det|> Small compasses are used to determine the direction of a magnetic field. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 102, 920, 135]]<|/det|> Which diagram shows the direction that the compass needles point when placed near the N and S poles of a bar magnet? <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[306, 147, 327, 165]]<|/det|> <|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[180, 170, 448, 210]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[670, 147, 690, 165]]<|/det|> <|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[544, 170, 814, 210]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[304, 247, 326, 266]]<|/det|> <|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[180, 271, 448, 310]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[670, 247, 690, 265]]<|/det|> <|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[544, 271, 814, 310]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 331, 107, 350]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 331, 730, 350]]<|/det|> A metal bar is placed inside a current-carrying coil, as shown in diagram 1. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 362, 813, 380]]<|/det|> There is a small current in the coil. The bar holds a few nails, as shown in diagram 2. <|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[218, 388, 776, 485]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 500, 559, 517]]<|/det|> When there is no current in the coil, the nails drop off. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 530, 297, 547]]<|/det|> Which row is correct? <|ref|>table<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 559, 625, 705]]<|/det|>
metal from which the bar is madeeffect of a larger current in the coil
Asoft ironit makes no difference
Bsoft ironthe bar holds more nails
Csteelit makes no difference
Dsteelthe bar holds more nails
<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 733, 104, 751]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 733, 920, 765]]<|/det|> There is a current \(I\) in a resistor of resistance \(R\). The potential difference (p.d.) across the resistor is \(V\). <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 778, 621, 796]]<|/det|> Which equation gives the power \(P\) dissipated by the resistor? <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 809, 134, 827]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 809, 210, 827]]<|/det|> \(P = IR\) <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[280, 808, 303, 827]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[316, 808, 379, 827]]<|/det|> \(P = IV\) <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[447, 807, 470, 826]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[473, 806, 544, 826]]<|/det|> \(P = \frac{I}{R}\) <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[613, 807, 636, 826]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[648, 806, 710, 826]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 72, 104, 88]]<|/det|>
<label>27</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 72, 589, 89]]<|/det|>
A student tests the electrical conduction of four materials.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[186, 102, 312, 119]]<|/det|>
● aluminium

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[186, 128, 260, 144]]<|/det|>
● iron

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[186, 154, 280, 170]]<|/det|>
● plastic

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[186, 180, 272, 196]]<|/det|>
● silver

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 209, 539, 227]]<|/det|>
Which materials are good conductors of electricity?

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 237, 134, 255]]<|/det|>
<label>A</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 237, 366, 255]]<|/det|>
aluminium, iron and silver

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 265, 131, 282]]<|/det|>
<label>B</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 265, 364, 282]]<|/det|>
aluminium and silver only

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 291, 131, 308]]<|/det|>
<label>C</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 291, 334, 307]]<|/det|>
iron, silver and plastic

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 317, 131, 335]]<|/det|>
<label>D</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 317, 248, 334]]<|/det|>
plastic only

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 361, 104, 380]]<|/det|>
<label>28</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 361, 917, 378]]<|/det|>
This question is about the potential difference (p.d.) across, and the current in, a variable resistor.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[351, 388, 645, 501]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 515, 537, 532]]<|/det|>
The resistance of the variable resistor is increased.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 545, 348, 562]]<|/det|>
Which statement is correct?

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 574, 131, 592]]<|/det|>
<label>A</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 574, 618, 591]]<|/det|>
The current can remain constant if the p.d. is decreased.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 600, 131, 618]]<|/det|>
<label>B</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[151, 600, 613, 617]]<|/det|>
The current can remain constant if the p.d. is increased.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 627, 131, 644]]<|/det|>
<label>C</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[151, 627, 640, 644]]<|/det|>
The p.d. can remain constant if the current is kept constant.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 653, 131, 670]]<|/det|>
<label>D</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[151, 653, 613, 670]]<|/det|>
The p.d. can remain constant if the current is increased.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 71, 106, 88]]<|/det|>
<label>29</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 71, 920, 104]]<|/det|>
Diagram 1 shows a resistor connected in a circuit. Diagram 2 shows an identical resistor connected in parallel with the first resistor.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[250, 112, 744, 265]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 275, 667, 295]]<|/det|>
What is the combined resistance of the two resistors in diagram 2?

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 305, 134, 324]]<|/det|>
<label>A</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 305, 467, 324]]<|/det|>
greater than in the circuit of diagram 1

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 331, 134, 350]]<|/det|>
<label>B</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 331, 625, 350]]<|/det|>
less than in the circuit of diagram 1, but greater than zero

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 357, 134, 375]]<|/det|>
<label>C</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 357, 467, 375]]<|/det|>
the same as in the circuit of diagram 1

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 383, 134, 401]]<|/det|>
<label>D</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 383, 193, 401]]<|/det|>
zero

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 427, 104, 446]]<|/det|>
<label>30</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 427, 608, 446]]<|/det|>
Where must a fuse be connected in a mains electric circuit?

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 456, 134, 475]]<|/det|>
<label>A</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 456, 306, 475]]<|/det|>
the earth wire only

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 483, 134, 502]]<|/det|>
<label>B</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 483, 293, 502]]<|/det|>
the live wire only

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 509, 134, 528]]<|/det|>
<label>C</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 509, 322, 528]]<|/det|>
the neutral wire only

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 536, 134, 554]]<|/det|>
<label>D</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 536, 406, 554]]<|/det|>
the live wire and the earth wire

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 72, 106, 88]]<|/det|>
<label>31</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 71, 920, 106]]<|/det|>
Which graph does **not** show the correct trend for the force \(F\) causing the turning effect on the coil in a d.c. motor?

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[201, 112, 789, 428]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 452, 106, 471]]<|/det|>
<label>32</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 452, 601, 471]]<|/det|>
Which statement about the structure of an atom is correct?

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 481, 134, 500]]<|/det|>
<label>A</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 481, 539, 500]]<|/det|>
Negative electrons surround a neutral nucleus.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 508, 134, 526]]<|/det|>
<label>B</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 508, 544, 526]]<|/det|>
Negative electrons surround a positive nucleus.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 534, 134, 553]]<|/det|>
<label>C</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 534, 532, 552]]<|/det|>
Positive electrons surround a neutral nucleus.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 560, 134, 579]]<|/det|>
<label>D</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[151, 560, 544, 579]]<|/det|>
Positive electrons surround a negative nucleus.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 603, 106, 622]]<|/det|>
<label>33</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 603, 631, 622]]<|/det|>
Four statements about isotopes of a certain element are listed.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 634, 561, 652]]<|/det|>
Which statement about the isotopes **must** be correct?

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 661, 134, 680]]<|/det|>
<label>A</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 661, 327, 680]]<|/det|>
They are radioactive.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 688, 134, 707]]<|/det|>
<label>B</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[151, 688, 308, 707]]<|/det|>
They are unstable.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 715, 134, 733]]<|/det|>
<label>C</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[151, 715, 494, 733]]<|/det|>
They have the same number of neutrons.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 740, 134, 759]]<|/det|>
<label>D</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[151, 740, 484, 759]]<|/det|>
They have the same number of protons.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 785, 106, 803]]<|/det|>
<label>34</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 784, 732, 803]]<|/det|>
What makes a contribution to a person's annual dose of ionising radiation?

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 813, 134, 831]]<|/det|>
<label>A</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 813, 274, 831]]<|/det|>
food and drink

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 840, 134, 858]]<|/det|>
<label>B</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[151, 840, 308, 858]]<|/det|>
greenhouse gases

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 866, 134, 885]]<|/det|>
<label>C</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[151, 866, 322, 885]]<|/det|>
mobile phone masts

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 892, 134, 911]]<|/det|>
<label>D</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[151, 892, 381, 910]]<|/det|>
radio and TV transmissions

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 72, 107, 89]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 72, 853, 89]]<|/det|> The emissions from a radioactive source pass through a sheet of lead that is \(10 \text{mm}\) thick. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 102, 920, 135]]<|/det|> Which type of radiation is emitted from the source and how is the radiation affected by an electric field? <|ref|>table<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 147, 672, 273]]<|/det|>
type of radiationeffect of electric field on radiation
Aαradiation deflected
Bαradiation not deflected
Cγradiation deflected
Dγradiation not deflected
<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 303, 107, 320]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 301, 920, 335]]<|/det|> Radioactive waste is often mixed with liquid glass. This mixture solidifies and is stored in steel drums. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 348, 551, 365]]<|/det|> Why is this process used to store radioactive waste? <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 375, 133, 393]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 375, 364, 393]]<|/det|> It reduces the decay rate. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 402, 133, 420]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 402, 443, 420]]<|/det|> It reduces the half-life of the waste. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 428, 131, 446]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 428, 645, 445]]<|/det|> The waste is contained in a solid block so it cannot leak out. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 454, 133, 472]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 454, 574, 471]]<|/det|> The glass is transparent so the waste can be seen. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 498, 106, 515]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 497, 470, 515]]<|/det|> Which planet is classed as a rocky planet? <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 526, 133, 545]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 526, 212, 545]]<|/det|> Jupiter <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 553, 133, 571]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 553, 212, 570]]<|/det|> Saturn <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 580, 133, 597]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 580, 217, 597]]<|/det|> Uranus <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 606, 133, 623]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 606, 212, 623]]<|/det|> Venus <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 650, 106, 667]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 650, 497, 667]]<|/det|> What is the cause of the phases of the Moon? <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 677, 133, 695]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 677, 507, 695]]<|/det|> the movement of the Earth around the Sun <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 704, 133, 721]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 704, 510, 721]]<|/det|> the movement of the Moon around the Sun <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 731, 133, 749]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 731, 520, 749]]<|/det|> the movement of the Moon around the Earth <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 757, 133, 775]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 757, 510, 775]]<|/det|> the movement of the Sun around the Moon <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 801, 106, 819]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 801, 368, 819]]<|/det|> What makes up the Universe? <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 829, 133, 848]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 829, 356, 848]]<|/det|> many billions of galaxies <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 856, 133, 874]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 856, 774, 874]]<|/det|> Mercury, Venus, the Earth, Mars, Jupiter, Saturn, Uranus and Neptune only <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 883, 133, 900]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 883, 463, 900]]<|/det|> the Sun, the Earth and the Moon only <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 909, 133, 926]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 909, 336, 926]]<|/det|> the Solar System only

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 179, 324, 196]]<|/det|>
